column4: hi, I have large list of files, how do I get total of space taken?
the s part means "only give me the total"
well yes, but if I do du -hsc $(mylist_of_files) it fails because that's just too many arguments..
don't tell it which files and it will just do the total of the current directory
these files are in different directories :/
I've run that command on my ENTIRE home folder (over 600GB of stuff) without issue (took a while though :P)
are they the only files in those directories?
nope, there's a ton of stuff there :)
ok. May I ask what types of files these are, this seems like a fairly strange request
well, we have web app and these are files that were marked as deleted in the database but are not physically deleted from filesystem..
ah, ok. well, you could run "for i in $my_list_of_files; do ln -s $i; done" in an empty directory, then run "du -hsL" from that directory
just make sure you don't have any spaces in your filenames. if you do, a "while read" loop should fix it
Darwin4Ever, ok, got it.. cat undeleted_files | xargs du -s | cut -f 1 | awk '{total = total + $1}END{print total}'
but don't use cat, use xarg's "-a undeleted_files" argument instead
and since you are checking files one at a time, the -s is pointless
